etymology.description: Pictogram of a pair of elephant tusks; per Xu Shen, used for human molars but not incisors (齒).
etymology.interpretation: Early forms depict two protruding tusks, a vivid image of hard, pointed teeth. Traditional scholarship narrowed its reference to back teeth, contrasting with 齒 for general teeth or incisors.

examples.chinese: 我牙疼(我牙疼)，需要看牙医(需要看牙醫)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yá téng, xūyào kàn yáyī.
examples.english: My tooth hurts; I need to see a dentist.

examples.chinese: 大象的象牙很珍贵(大象的象牙很珍貴)。
小孩开始换牙(小孩開始換牙)，长出新门牙了(長出新門牙了)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎohái kāishǐ huàn yá, zhǎngchū xīn ményá le.
examples.english: The child has started to lose teeth and grow new front teeth.
